sentence.text: A 28-year-old parous woman was referred to our health service at 35 weeks’ gestation.
The patient and her partner are second-degree consanguineous with no significant personal or family history.
A first trimester ultrasound raised the suspicion of short long bones.
At 16 weeks, the long bones remained shortened with fixed flexion bilaterally at the elbow, wrist, and knee joints as well as bilateral talipes.
An amniocentesis performed at this time confirmed the genetic diagnosis of Bruck syndrome.
Serial scans continued to document severe shortening of the long bones, eventually lagging 10 weeks behind dates at 33 weeks’ gestation.
In addition, the long bones progressively appeared more angulated and fractured.
By mid-gestation, bilateral fractures of the femur and humerus were diagnosed, and kyphosis of the lower lumbar spine was documented.
At 35 weeks’ gestation, the woman was transferred to our tertiary centre, given its co-location with the Children’s Hospital, in view of new-onset fetal cardiac findings.
On arrival, joint assessment by the maternal fetal medicine and fetal cardiology team was performed.
The fetus was in breech presentation and in addition to the known skeletal features, significant cardiomegaly was noted.
The right heart was enlarged (shown in Fig. 4), secondary to severe tricuspid valve regurgitation, pulmonary valve insufficiency, and a small arterial duct.
The left heart structures were normal, with preserved biventricular systolic function and a normal atrial rhythm.
There was no history of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory intake during the pregnancy.
Mid-trimester cardiac screening had reported normal cardiac size and connections.
The working diagnosis of new onset significant right heart pathology in combination with a small arterial duct included premature restriction of the ductus arteriosus.
Delivery was planned 12 h later, after administration of a single 11.4 mg dose of betamethasone.
At 35+5 weeks, a live male baby was delivered by caesarean section, weighing 2,500 g with Apgar scores of 3 and 6 at 1 and 5 min, respectively.
Care was taken to ensure a gentle delivery, including administration of intravenous glyceryl trinitrate 200 µg for uterine relaxation as well as en-caul delivery of the infant.
The operator continuously supported the fetal body and head to allow the infant to be delivered in one movement avoiding manipulation of the limbs and the spine.
The neonate was immediately placed onto a sterile plastic drape which supported the fetus during transfer to the resuscitator.
Features of facial dysmorphism as well as a pan-systolic murmur were noted on initial examination.
The newborn required immediate intubation and was transferred to the neonatal intensive care unit on 100% FiO2.
Following birth, the limb fractures and contractures were clinically evident, and a cardiac echocardiogram confirmed tricuspid valve dysplasia with severe regurgitation.
There was antegrade flow across the pulmonary valve and the arterial duct was restrictive (shown in Fig. 5, 6, respectively).
There were additional findings of an anterior mitral valve prolapse with mild mitral regurgitation and mild impairment of left ventricular systolic function.
Cardiac management was directed towards rapid reduction of pulmonary vascular resistance to reduce right ventricular afterload and encourage antegrade flow through the right heart.
Bisphosphonates were commenced for the skeletal anomalies.
The admission was further complicated by a pulmonary haemorrhage and the infant succumbed at day 44 of life.
